course_title: Roles and Opportunities in Speech Pathology

learning_outcomes.description: Describe the roles and ethical responsibilities of speech pathologists across a range of professional contexts (SPA PS Domains/Standards 1.1 1.7, 2.1 2.7, 3.1 3.6).

Explain how current and emerging technologies are used to support speech pathology practice, including considerations of access, safety and professional responsibility (SPA PS Domains/Standards 1.1 1.3, 1.5, 1.7, 2.6, 3.2, 3.4 and 3.5).
Demonstrate professional communication skills and emerging professional identity in preparation for entering the speech pathology workforce (SPA PS Domains/Standards 2.5, 2.6, 2.7, 3.6).
Apply foundational principles of problem-solving and innovation to identify potential contributions to speech pathology services and practice (SPA PS Domains/Standards 2.7, 3.4).
Work collaboratively in professional teams (SPA PS Domains/Standards 1.4, 2.3, 2.5, 2.6, 3.1, 3.3, 3.4).

assessments.assessment_title: Employability Part A: Job Application Package
assessments.task_description:
This assessment requires students to demonstrate understanding of the application process for a speech pathology role by preparing a professional application package. 

Students will respond to one (1) of three (3) job advertisements by writing a cover letter and answering selection criteria as specified in the advertisement. Students will also provide a mock LinkedIn profile that will be viewed by your prospective employer as part of the application process. A detailed task description and rubric will be provided on the SPCH4113 Blackboard site. 

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit one (1) electronic copy via the SPCH4113 Blackboard site, attaching a signed SHRS coversheet. Note: when a student submits an assignment or test, a window appears with a submission confirmation number. Students can download a copy of the receipt directly from the window. They also receive a copy of their submission receipt via an automatic email confirmation. Students are encouraged to save their submission receipts to verify they submitted their work.

assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.

assessments.assessment_title: Future of Speech Pathology Group Presentation
assessments.due_date:
30/03/2026 - 31/03/2026

All groups must submit their Clinical Bite session plan and associated multimedia via Blackboard by 1pm on Monday 30th March. Groups should nominate one (1) group member to submit the required materials. Presentations will take place during students' timetabled class in week 6 of semester (Tuesday 31st March). Attendance is expected at all presentations.

If a student is unable to attend due to medical or other valid reasons, the group is still expected to complete the task collectively during the tutorial and receive a group mark.
assessments.task_description:
Students will work in groups to present a 15-minute Clinical Bite on "The Future of Speech Pathology". Each group will need to develop a persuasive, innovative, and engaging learning activity to inform the audience of how they perceive the future of speech pathology practice to look in a specific context. Each group will be allocated a different context to consider in their presentation. 

A detailed task description and rubric will be provided on the SPCH4113 Blackboard site. Students will be marked on both the quality and content of their presentation (20%) and a peer assessment on teamwork (5%).

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

When a student is required to complete an oral or practical assessment item worth 20% or more, the performance will be recorded and retained per Appendix 1 (Assessment Procedure (95)).
assessments.submission_guidelines: One (1) group member should submit the group's Clinical Bite session plan and associated multimedia through the Blackboard submission link.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.assessment_title: Integrating Technology into Future Practice Video Assignment
assessments.task_description:
The goal of this assignment is to encourage students to critically reflect on the role of technology in clinical settings and develop strategies for effectively integrating technological tools into their future practice.

Students will create a 4-5 minute video presentation outlining how they plan to incorporate technology into their clinical work as a future speech-language pathologist. Students may use slides, screen recordings, and/or visual aids to enhance their presentation. 

A detailed task description and rubric will be provided on the SPCH4113 Blackboard site. 

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Students should submit the video in a commonly supported format via the relevant assessment link in Blackboard. A copy of your script for this presentation should be uploaded as a separate file to the same Blackboard submission portal.

assessments.due_date: The interviews will be scheduled during the End of Semester Exam Period.
assessments.task_description:
Students will participate in a group job interview comprising both individual questions and completion of a group task. Students will be informed of the associated job context 1 week prior to the scheduled interview. All students will be marked individually based on their performance.

A detailed task description and rubric will be provided on the SPCH4113 Blackboard site. Students will have an opportunity to practice a 'group interview task' in week 2 of semester during scheduled class time.

When a student is required to complete an oral or practical assessment item worth 20% or more, the performance will be recorded and retained per Appendix 1 (Assessment Procedure (95)).

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of Generative AI may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

learning_activities.topic:
Self-Directed Learning

Students are required to access weekly content via Blackboard and complete the necessary learning activities prior to each tutorial. Content includes in depth exploration of roles and opportunities in different speech pathology contexts, factors impacting the profession both now and in the future (e.g., telepractice, technology and AI), and applying for jobs in speech pathology.
